content: The "Hong Kong Reversion Act" aims to support Hong Kong's autonomous governance and well-being after its reversion to China in 1997. It outlines circumstances for the US President to modify laws if China fails to uphold Hong Kong's autonomy. The Congress findings highlight the binding international agreement between the UK and China regarding the reversion of Hong Kong in 1997. China pledged autonomy, human rights, and elections for Hong Kong. Despite assurances from senior Chinese officials for a smooth transfer of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty and respect for the region's autonomy, there have been concerning actions such as attempts to infringe on Hong Kong's autonomy, including proposals for loyalty oaths for civil servants. The curr_chunk discusses various concerning actions by the Government of the People's Republic of China regarding Hong Kong, including obtaining confidential files on civil servants, dissolving the Legislative Council, restricting speech and association, warnings to religious institutions, and amending Hong Kong ordinances. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China decided on February 23, 1997, to repeal or amend certain Hong Kong ordinances, including the Bill of Rights Ordinance, Societies Ordinance of 1992, and Public Order Ordinance of 1995. Despite commitments in the Joint Declaration, UK government acts have damaged Hong Kong's autonomy, such as agreements on the Court of Final Appeal and limiting democratically-elected seats in the Legislative Council. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 outlines US policy regarding Hong Kong's reversion to China in 1997 and its special status as a Special Administrative Region. It emphasizes protecting US interests during and after the transition and ensuring the human rights of the Hong Kong people. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 ensures the continuity of US laws regarding Hong Kong's autonomy and provides a mechanism for the President to modify the application of these laws if Hong Kong is deemed not sufficiently autonomous. The Act aims to maintain Hong Kong's distinct legal entity status. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 aims to maintain Hong Kong's autonomy as a distinct legal entity separate from China. It requires the Secretary of State to evaluate the implementation of the Joint Declaration, emphasizing that Hong Kong's future depends on China's commitment to maintaining the freedoms of its people. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL DECLARATIONS. Congress makes the following declarations regarding the close relationship between the United States and Hong Kong, emphasizing the importance of cooperation, respecting Hong Kong's autonomy, and considering the historical significance of Hong Kong as a port of call for US naval vessels. The United States urges China to consider US requests for port calls in Hong Kong, emphasizes the importance of a free press and access to information for Hong Kong's success, and criticizes the provisional legislature's election law for disadvantaging popular political parties. The United States criticizes Hong Kong's election laws for disadvantaging popular political parties and calls for elections to be conducted according to laws approved by the people or their representatives. The US also declares that the failure to have an elected legislature would violate the Joint Declaration and urges China to honor its treaty obligations. Additionally, the US emphasizes the importance of preserving essential rights and freedoms for the Hong Kong people. The United States supports the Bill of Rights Ordinance in Hong Kong, emphasizing the importance of protecting the freedom to associate and assemble. It calls for revisions of Hong Kong law to be left to a democratically-elected legislature and welcomes the Chief Executive-designate's commitment to replace repealed sections of certain ordinances. The United States supports Hong Kong's commitment to public consultation on new legislation, urging it to align with the wishes of the people and international human rights standards. It calls on China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and independence in maintaining its efficient economy and rule of law. The United States urges China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and independence, including the chief executive, civil service, judiciary, police, and Independent Commission Against Corruption. The United States calls on China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy, including its chief executive, civil service, judiciary, police, and Independent Commission Against Corruption. Presidential determination under the United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 and additional reporting requirements are emphasized. The President will assess Hong Kong's autonomy to determine its treatment under US laws, considering the performance of the Hong Kong Government and actions of China. The Secretary of State must report on the existence of a freely elected legislature in Hong Kong. The Secretary will assess the existence of a freely elected legislature in Hong Kong based on the ability of the people to participate in elections without restrictions. Additionally, the Secretary will evaluate the successful conclusion of agreements and treaties, including a bilateral investment treaty, an extradition treaty, and an agreement on consular access in Hong Kong. The Secretary will assess agreements or treaties including a bilateral investment treaty, extradition treaty, consular access agreement, preservation of the US consulate, mutual legal assistance agreement, prison transfer agreement, and civil aviation agreement in Hong Kong. Additionally, the Secretary will evaluate continued cooperation from Hong Kong government agencies in areas such as customs enforcement, drug interdiction, and prosecution. The Secretary will assess the cooperation between Hong Kong and the United States in areas like customs enforcement, drug interdiction, and prosecution. The assessment will also include the preservation of good governance, rule of law, and autonomy in Hong Kong, looking at efforts to restrict civil liberties and interfere with the chief executive's autonomy. The Secretary will assess the application of laws against treason, secession, sedition, and subversion in Hong Kong, as well as interference in autonomy, increased corruption, and suppression of freedom of the press. Additionally, the assessment will include the preservation of Hong Kong's customs territory autonomy, looking at failures to respect US textile laws, enforce export control laws, and unauthorized diversions of high technology exports. The assessment will also cover the unprecedented diversion of Chinese exports through Hong Kong to gain preferential treatment in US markets and the misuse of Hong Kong's customs territory to advance the foreign policy or trade goals of China. SEC. 6. Prohibition on the use of funds for the participation of Hong Kong provisional legislature in certain United States Information Agency programs. No funds for the United States Information Agency can be used for any member of the Hong Kong provisional legislature to participate in USIA programs. The Hong Kong provisional legislature is defined as the body appointed in 1996 to replace the elected Legislative Council. SEC. 7. Definition. The term "Joint Declaration" refers to the agreement between the UK and China on Hong Kong in 1984.
